I strongly sympathize with nearly all the complaints of the OWS protesters, but I am also afraid that they do not understand those of us (including the author/s of this article) who say that it is not enough to be angry and express that anger in a "wholesale," generalized way. To be effective, they have to advance specific demands. Anyone who carefully reads the comments by posters who identify themselves as OWS protesters can synthesize from among the many perfectly legitimate and justified, but generic, complaints certain specific problems that can be put in the form of specific demands. In the hope that this may be at least marginally helpful to the protesters, I am suggesting below, for a start, two specific demands that seem to emerge most frequently from from those legitimate and justified complaints.

1. Institute public financing of political campaigns and elections. This is a "biggie", a truly revolutionary proposal, for several reasons: (a) Unlike our neighbor – Canada, and our closest European ally – Great Britain, this country has never had this system. (b) There is some ridiculous Supreme Court precedent that equates political money contributions with “speech,” and thus extends to them the constitutional protection of freedom of speech. (I say “ridiculous” because it compares your and my individual voice with the deafening roar of Exxon-Mobil, Goldman-Sachs or Microsoft) So this would be an uphill battle, but it is cause entirely worthy of all the efforts and sacrifices of the OWS demonstrators.
2. Reenact the Glass-Steagall Act or its current formulation – the Volcker Rule. This would prohibit banks from commingling its “commercial” (aka “retail”) banking operations with their investment operations, and do away with the incongruity of an “investment bank.” (You are either a bank or an investment brokerage, not both). It would also prosecute any banker who invested a depositor’s money in such semi-fictitious instruments as various derivatives.
